ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20628/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of maize silage(fresh matter).; ;;There is no irrigation to this crop production.;References:;May et al., 2015: Contributions from experts here listed: André May, Embrapa Milho e Sorgo, andre.may@embrapa.br; Marília I. Dourados: Embrapa Agropecuária Oeste, 2007. p. 44-61. (EmbrapaAgropecuária Oeste. Final report ecoinvent v2.0 nº 15a. Viçosa: Universidade Federal de Viçosa, p. 399.;Zolin, Cornelio Alberto et al. (2016) Perda de solo e agua sob integracao lavoura-floresta e em sucessao soja-milho. Pesquisa Agropecuária Brasileira, Brasília, v. 51, n. 9, p.1223-1230, set. 2016. Disponível em: <http://www.scielo.br/pdf/pab/v51n9/0100-;Anjos & Mattiazzo (2000). Metais pesados em plantas de milho cultivadas em latossolos repetidamente tratados com biossolido. Scientia Agricola, v. 57, n, 4, p,769-776, out-dez 2000. Available in <http://www.scielo.br/pdf/sa/v57n4/a27v57n4.pdf> Accessed in 15 feb 2017.;Bordin, Ivan et al. (2008) Materia seca, carbono e nitrogenio de raizes de soja e milho em plantio direto e convencional. Pesquisa Agropecuaria Brasileira, Brasilia, v. 43, n. 12, p. 1785-1792, dez. 2008. Available in <https://seer.sct.embrapa.br/index.php/pab/article/view/1087> Acessed in: 07 mar. 2017.;Coelho, Antonio Marcos (2007). Manejo da adubacao nitrogenada na cultura do milho. Embrapa Milho e Sorgo, Sete Lagoas, dez. 2007. Available in <http://www.cnpms.embrapa.br/publicacoes/publica/2007/circular/Circ_96.pdf> Acessed in: 22 mar. 2017.;Novaes, Renan M. L. et al. (2017) Estimating 20-year land use change and derived CO2 emissions associated with crops, parture and forestry in Brazil and each of its 27 states. Global Change Biology, 2017, 1-13.;Nemecek T., Bengoa X., Lansche J., Mouron  P., Riedener E., Rossi V. & Humbert S. (2015) Methodological Guidelines for the Life Cycle Inventory of Agricultural Products. Version 3.0, July 2015. World Food LCA Database (WFLDB). Quantis and Agroscope, Lausanne and Zurich, Switzerland.;CRUZ, J.C.; PEREIRA FILHO, I.A.; RODRIGUES, J.A.S.; FERREIRA, J.J. (Eds.) Produção e utilização de silagem de milho e sorgo. Sete Lagoas: Embrapa Milho e Sorgo, 2001. 544p.;IBGE, 2017. Levantamento Sistemático da Produção Agrícola Tabela 1618 - Área plantada, área colhida e produção, por ano da safra e produto. https://sidra.ibge.gov.br/Tabela/1618;Dataset authors:; Fernando Rodrigues Teixeira Dias, fernando.dias@embrapa.br; Leticia De S. Barrantes, leticia.desantib@gmail.com; Andre May, andre.may@embrapa.br; Marília I. S. Folegatti Matsuura, marilia.folegatti@embrapa.br; Jane Rodrigues de Assis Machado, Embrapa Milho e Sorgo, jane.machado@embrapa.br; Cláudio Doro, Emater Passo Fundo-RS, cdoro@emater.tche.br.2016

This activity starts after the harvest of the previous crop.

The dataset includes the inputs of seeds, mineral fertilisers and pesticides. It is assumed that no organic fertilisers are applied.
The dataset also includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Machine operations are: limestone and gypsum application, by spreader; application of plant protection product, by field sprayer; planting with starter fertiliser, by no till planter; fertilising, by broadcaster; and chopping and fodder loading. Includes the transportation of products inside the farm:  water from water source to field, fertilisers from farm gate to field and grains from harvester to truck.
Furthermore, direct field and land use change emissions are included, with important regionalizations added. Due to phosphorus low mobility in Brazilian soils, its emissions through leaching and run-off were disregarded.
The dataset doesn't include: storage and serving the silage. 
The activity ends after harvest at the farm gate. There is no irrigation to this crop production.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0119:Growing of other non-perennial crops

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Time period of the most of the data collected for this dataset.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for the state of Rio Grande do Sul, in Brazil, but supposed to be a good approximation for the whole country.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Cultivation of maize like first harvest of grains in cropping system (e.g. maize followed by wheat), but adapted for silage, with no following crop on the same area the same year.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
A system for maize grain production was used as basis for the maize silage BR production. The maize grain system used corresponds to the northwest region of Rio Grande do Sul state that represents 24% of the total production in BR-RS, according to grains survey from IBGE/SIDRA (2016) (https://sidra.ibge.gov.br/home/ipca15/brasil). 
Carbon content, water content and gross calorific value are based on ecoinvent database for all exchanges.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
The main source of data for agricultural inputs and operations are projects conducted by Embrapa Milho e Sorgo (CNPMS) and Embrapa Soja (CNPSO). Data are also provided by relevant experts related to agricultural sector of maize in Rio Grande do Sul state (BR). 
Emissions from the agricultural process are estimated according to Nemecek and Schnetzer (2011) and Canals (2003). 
This model for the maize silage production for cattle feed was based on the system for maize grain production used in the northwest region of Rio Grande do Sul state. This maize grain production system was chosen as basis for estimating maize silage production exchanges because it is one of the last systems in Brazil that do not depend on rotation with soybean (that does not occur in maize silage production, either). Fertilisers, pesticides and al other exchanges used were assumed to be the same use for the maize grain production system, adjusted proportionally to the yield for maize silage production usual in Brazil, that is much higher for maize silage, as it includes most of the plant: 5 kg/m2/year; and with a much higher moisture content: 65% of water content in wet mass. Pedigree matrix was adjusted for all exchanges considering these assumptions.

Potassium fertiliser used is K2O, phosphate fertiliser used is P2O5 (87,5 kg/ha/year each), nitrogen fertiliser used is urea (130 kg/ha/year).

Pesticides used are atrazine (2,5 kg/ha/year, glyphosate (720 g/ha/year) and other unspecified (720 g/ha/year).

exchanges.description: 1 Kg of maize silage produced used as reference. The corn cob and part of the straw is included, part of the straw and root is left on the field.

flow.name: maize silage
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0119:Growing of other non-perennial crops

exchanges.description: Agricultural operation. Amount for typical system from May et al. (2016) alocated between maize and wheat in cropping system where maize occupies the ground for four months plus the fallow period and limestone is applied each three years.

exchanges.description: Emissions of heavy metals to soil and surface water estimated from mineral fertilisers and liming as recommended by Canals (2003), metal content in maize from Anjos & Mattiazzo (2000). Nemecek & Schnetzer (2011) state that "some of the values for emissions of heavy metals to the soil are negative. This means that more heavy metals are exported than imported. It must, however, be borne in mind that these heavy metals are transferred either to the water bodies or to the products harvested from the field".

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of fertilisers needed for the production of 'maize silage' is calculated to be circa 1.93E-02 kg. Fertiliser/s used in this dataset is/are: 'lime', 'phosphate fertiliser, as P2O5', 'potassium fertiliser, as K2O', 'urea, as N'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of fertiliser/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 3.86E-02 kg of packaging for fertilisers is justified with this exchange.

exchanges.description: Transports inside the field of: grains (total distance = 0.6 km/ha; total load = 0.6 t/ha), side dressing fertiliser (total distance = 0.14 km/ha; total load = 0.14 t/ha), starter fertiliser (total distance = 0.16 km/ha; total load = 0.16 t/ha) and water (total distance = 0.13 km/ha; total load = 0.13 t/ha) respectively. Amount for typical system from May et al. (2016). Transport of water from the water source to the field to supply the pesticide sprayer. Long distances are involved in maize production in Brasil what makes necessary the transportation, e.g., of water from the captation to the application in order to keep the operation of pesticide spraying continuos. Amount for typical system from May et al. (2016).

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of pesticides needed for the production of maize silage is calculated to be circa 7.83E-05 kg. Pesticide/s used in this dataset is/are: 'atrazine', 'glyphosate', 'pesticide, unspecified'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of pesticide/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 1.57E-04 kg of packaging for pesticides is justified with this exchange.
